description.narrative: The development objectives of Institutional Capacity Building Project for Uzbekistan is to strengthen public financial management (PFM) and enable the market operation of the corporate sector. This project has four components. 1) The first component, Improving PFM, aims to support improvements in areas fundamental to a functional PFM system that promotes achievement of public policy objectives, improved performance, and institutionalized accountability. 2) The second component, Improving conditions for market operation of the corporate sector, aims to support the restructuring and rightsizing of the State-Owned Enterprise (SOE) sector in Uzbekistan. 3) The third component, Improving Support Mechanisms for Reforms, aims to provide support to the newly established Economic Council, key regulatory agencies and other public sector agencies expected to be identified as critical for implementing market reforms during project implementation. 4) The fourth component, Project management, aims to provide support to the overall implementation arrangements for the project.

condition.narrative: Legal covenants in the Financing Agreement (Schedule 2, Section I, A) include:(a) Establishment of an automated accountinginformation system (due no later than 1 month after effectiveness date.)(b) Establishment of a Project Implementation AdvisoryBoard (due no later than 2 months after effectiveness date)

title.narrative: Staff trained on all PFM areas (of which female)

target.value: 400 (of which 100% of potential female beneficiaries are included)

title.narrative: Number of PPPs developed for the market
Number of Advisory Notes Prepared by technical experts to support the work of the Council
No. of new laws and regulations reviewed by the Economic Council
Number of SOEs privatization public calls announced
Number of bids received per privatization transaction
Number of bids received per PPP transaction
Boards are formed at largest 30 SOEs and given an authority and competencies for strategic guidance and monitoring of SOE management
Largest SOEs follow high standards of transparency and are subject to the high quality accounting, disclosure, compliance and auditing standards, as per Chapter VI of the OECD Guidelines
Number of SOE restructuring plans adopted
Number of SOEs privatized (more than 50% of shares divested) and number of infrastructure PPPs completed

Staff trained on corporate governance, privatization and PPP development (of which female)
Percentage of SOEs using IFRS for financial reporting and publicly disclosing the reports

baseline.value: 2018 PEFA Scores are D for PI 8.1, 8.2, and 8.3; PI 16.2 and 16.3; and PI 17.2

target.value: Marked improvements in PEFA Assessments - score of C for PI 8.1, 8.2 and 8.4; PI 16.2 and 16.3 and PI 17.2

actual.value: 2018 PEFA Scores are D for PI 8.1, 8.2, and 8.3; PI 16.2 and 16.3; and PI 17.2

title.narrative: Corporate governance of SOEs reflects OECD Corporate Governance Standards

baseline.value: Newly created agency with low capacity (ASAM)

target.value: SOE aggregate report for Top [30] produced and published by SOE ownership agency

actual.value: Draft Presidential Decree approving application of OECD principle guidelines

title.narrative: 3 Core legislative acts reviewed and updated

baseline.value: Outdated laws on accounting, auditing and corporate governance

actual.value: SOE Strategy adopted (March 2021) incl Corp Governance provisions. Accounting and Audit Laws updated, IFRS and ISA adopted viaGovernment Regulation. State Property Management Law commented by the WB, exp to be adopted by Dec 2021.

title.narrative: New laws/regulations on PPP enacted and implemented

target.value: New laws on PPP under implementation
Multiyear investment planning introduced in 50% of ministries and a sustainable training program and capacity established.

title.narrative: New public sector accounting and financial reporting standards implemented following international good practices

target.value: Piloting completed. Applicable accounting and financial reporting standards and software updated based on lessons from pilot.Certification system for new standards initiated. 50 trainers trained and training program developed.
Gradual implementation of the new IA methodology and new IA management software in 30% of line ministries. 20 trainers trained andtraining program developed

title.narrative: New public internal control framework implemented following international good practices

target.value: Gradual roll-out of new PIC framework with 10% at the central level of government implementing. 50 trainers trained and trainingprogram developed.

title.narrative: Budgeting processes, public internal control and audit, and public sector accounting standards reflect international good practices

target.value: PEFA indicators related to budget improved, internal control and audit follows international good practices, accounting followsIPSAS

title.narrative: 3 monitoring tools adopted for SOE oversight and governance

baseline.value: Weak monitoring of SOE fin performance and corporate governance arrangements

target.value: 3 tools adopted (SOE performance monitoring framework, KPIs in line with good practices, and SOE performance monitoring portal)

actual.value: Weak monitoring of SOE fin performance and corporate governance arrangements
